This is a long email but I type fast and have alot of info for you ladies.here goes....I started IVF 2 years ago and started DHEA 1 year ago after 3 failed IVF cycles. I now have 10 embryos on ice and am in the middle of what we hope to be our last cycle.After alot of experimentation and mis-steps, our last cycle yielded 10 eggs, 5 were unfortunately immature but the other 5 all fertilized.I had 14 antral follicles at baseline last week and tomorrow is day 6 scan.Couple basics from my experience.1. DHEA works - I recommend to everyone get your DHEA-S and Testosterone levels tested and take DHEA dosage based on those levels. The very low doses being suggested only work if your T is already normal...but most of us with poor response will have low T and need the DHEA. If your T is in the low or below normal range I really recommend 100mg/day.2. Take it in the morning - your body absorbs it in the early morning - first thing when you wake up.3. Test your T level after starting to take the DHEA to ensure that your body is absorbing it and your T level is rising. The goal range is in the high normal or, if you're a REALLY poor responder like me, I shoot to keep it at 100 pg/ml.4. Once you start, your ovaries will become very active. In order to suppress them and get best results, you need the estrogen patch. You WILL OVULATE THROUGH THE PILL. The pill is not enough to suppress your active ovaries. I start the patch right after ovulation, keep it on for 2 weeks, go off for 3 days, then start stims.5. Baseline exam should have E2 less than 30 and at least 8 antral follicles all about 5 mm. You don't want a leader follicle for sure...make sure they're all less than 7 mm. This will be your best circumstance for the investment. DH and I defined our own criteria in baseline after the docs always said....less than 10 looks good to go and we would get different sizes and not enough mature. So we set the rules after that and it has REALLY paid off. Min 8 antral follicles and all about 5 mm. The doc got frustrated when we went 3 months without starting a cycle but I just kept my cool and humor and he was really excited and humbled by the great results we eventually got.6. You will likely need to stim for longer than the usual. I have been stimming for on average 10 days. And the E2 takeoff/major increase, seems to start a bit later. The important thing is how many follicles you see on the follow up scans.Good luck ladies!***@****if you want to email put DHEA only in the subject and I'll pick them up as early as I can.

Hi Ladies – Long time! Sorry about that! Here are responses to your questions. This is a long one but I hope I’ve answered all your questions. And I promise to log in here more often! Desperado:  Congradulations on the conception but terribly sorry to hear about the miscarriage. Hang in there babe – you’ll get a babe yet. My recommendation is mortgage the house for IVF and PGD before time runs out. ;)  see response to your Qs  #1 and #2 below.Shayla: taking more is good. With your enthusiasm you’ll do great! Good luck! You are #3 belowJulie 1615: yes they have proven increased quality of embryos. Got to centerforhumanreproduction and read up there and/or follow the link to their published study. Hair loss is EXTREMELY rare with DHEA. DHEA shouldn’t be compared to acupuncture – do them BOTH. You are #5, 6, and 7 below. Best to you too!Frisbe: what a great name! I know how you felt…I felt the same way when I read the published research by Casson and Gleicher in 2000 and 2006 respectively. Be sure to ignore the naysayers sweety. You’ll find them everywhere. My husband calls doctors and nurses technicians instead of scientists. Even my own RE, despite all his support, still doesn’t recommend it outright to new patients. Doctors are most often extremely slow to change and embrace new protocols and they are afraid of doing more harm than good when wading into the abyss. Some goodies for you in  #8, 9, 10, 11 below. And see #2 – 4 for your second questions. I’ll look forward to hearing your updates!Blondemacb: I think its fine to take all at once in the morning but work at 100mg first if you go that route. Yes…my back and face broke out….but scrubbing with those hand scrubby gloves from Target helped somewhat. For you….I REALLY recommend counting your antral follicles before starting your last cycle. I had DOC scan me on day 15 and day 27 before my period for 3 months. Each month on DHEA I had 2 more until I had 10 antral follicles after my Testosterone had been up consistently for like 2 or 3 months. We were in the same boat as you…..on our last try and couldn’t take a chance of wasting it without seeing a minimum of 8 antral follicles before we said GO. See #12 below about the patch….this is important for you.BNF:  My Dear you are in a common predicament with many of us poor responders. If you can’t find a high quality doc to take you here’s a suggestion….challenge your doctor to scan your ovaries on day 20 and 27 of your cycle. Ask if he sees more activity will he reconsider. I promise you my dear he will see more follies and when you do IVF all of your mature eggs will fertilize. I’ve done 3 cycles and every mature egg I’ve gotten has fertilized normally. Also had a friend do the 100mg/day in the am for just a month and she got 4 eggs, all fertilized normally, and she’s got  the BFP! Hang in there….I would put $$ that you’ll be in another cycle within 2 – 3 months.1.	DHEA DOES WEAR OFF. I’ve been on high doses for a long time and within 2 weeks of stopping the DHEA altogether my testosterone level returned to its original very low level. My ovarian function has slowed visibly via ultrasound in one month. At this rate I am guessing that 4 – 6 weeks off DHEA after 4 months on it will return you to COMPLETEly original condition.2.	STOP DHEA BEFORE EMBRYO TRANSFER. DHEA increases your testosterone and high testosterone is a common cause of miscarriage. This is also reflected in the higher than normal miscarriage rate at CHR when they studied DHEA.3.	IF YOU DON”T HAVE 4 MONTHS TAKE MORE. In general I don’t think that 25mg 3x/day is going to work for more than 50% of women. If you get eggs and are just improving quality then I think it could be enough. If you get very few or no eggs then I recommend 100mg/day once in the morning. I would not take any more than 150 mg. I have experimented all the way up to 450mg/day and prematurely ovulated despite the proper injections to avoid it.4.	TAKE IT IN THE MORNING. After much research and my own switch from 3x/day to just the am I believe DHEA is primarily absorbed and converted to DHEA-S in the morning. So I took it 8am daily in my, what I’ll call second phase of experimenting. My Testosterone only then began to rise quite nicely and consistently and antral follicle count increase soon followed.5.	EMBRYO QUALITY YES, CHROMOSOME QUALITY STILL UNKNOWN. Note – you can have a normal chromosome setup in an embryo and also have  crappy embryonic (fluid) health. We know DHEA improves the fluid health but its not yet clear if you would get a higher number of PGD quality. Its also interesting to note that miscarriage can be higher with DHEA.6.	HAIR LOSS IS EXTREMELY RARE. Hair loss can occur with very very high levels of testosterone….like over 200ng/dl I believe. If you have few or no eggs then you likely have very very low testosterone and DHEA up to 150 mg/day should not raise your testosterone over 120ng/dl. Everyone is different so best to find a doc that will throw in DHEA-S and T to your blood work just to see that you’re not having some strange hyper reaction and getting very high Testosterone levels. These blood tests are very inexpensive.7.	DHEA BEST WITH ACCUPUNCTURE AND BABY ASPIRIN. Because DHEA increases your testosterone your red blood cell count will increase thus actually thickening your blood. So it is really good to do it with BABY ASPIRIN AND ACCUPUNCTURE to thin the blood a bit and get it over to your ovaries. Poor responders, in conjunction with low testosterone, can also have poor blood supply to the ovaries reducing your response and Accupuncture can take care of that.8.	TEST TESTOSTERONE AND DHEA-S ON DAY 1-2 & 14, AND ESTROGEN AND FSH ON DAY 1-2. Best if you can get these tests before you start for baseline. After a week on DHEA your DHEA-S should increase significantly, like anywhere from 50 to 100%. It WILL go well above normal but this had no ill effect on me even over 2000ug/dl. Get you lab results printed from your doctor and keep track. Don’t just take the verbal…’you’re above normal…within range…etc.’ you typically get from doc. Track this yourself because the docs do not have a basis in publication for evaluating this data.9.	BASELINE ESTROGEN GOES DOWN on DHEA. Poor responders typically have elevated baseline estrogen. DHEA can and should cut that elevated level in half after 2 months.10.	BASELINE FSH GOES DOWN on DHEA. Again..poor responders typically have elevated baseline FSH. I’ll spare you the biochem and just tell you that mine went from 11 to 3.5 and stayed there around 3 while on DHEA. There is a direct correlation between these and increasing your Testosterone level via DHEA.11.	ALCOHOL INTERFERES WITH DHEA-S – DON”T DRINK AND DO DHEA.12.	ESTROGEN PATCH TO DOWNREGULATE OVARIES BEFORE STIMMING. I ovulated through the pill 2 months straight while on DHEA and the doc wouldn’t believe it until he saw it. Another friend had the same experience. Finally my doc got advice from GLeicher who did the study. The only way to downregulate your ovaries once you’ve gotten higher testosterone from DHEA is the ESTROGEN PATCH. I had to use 2 patches and switch them every day just to keep all the follies at less than 7 mm before stimming.

I totally understand what you're dealing with. None of the REs are doing bloodwork because the studies published, other than CASSON in 2000 didn't track blood levels so they have nothing to go on. I tracked my blood for almost 2 years and 4 cycles. Please trust me tracking your blood is important and you need to just be firm and tell them you want it. They will give it to you if you demonstrate determination.  Tell them its very very important to you that they test DHEA-S and Testosterone (T) free and total at least bi-weekly and your FSH and E2 on day 2 of cycle. You will likely find your T in the low range to start. I recommend taking DHEA at doses increasing by 25mg every 2 weeks until you can see your T close to 100ng/dl. And get the lab report print out from them...and track this yourself. This is your money and your baby....I firmly believe you need to find a doctor who will at least allow you to test your DHEA-S and T twice a month until you start your cycle. I rolled over to doctors for 3 cycles and lots of $$ and failure before I finally went on the search for a doctor who would work with me.I just had a transfer yesterday of 2 hatching pgd quality blasts out of 5 tested at age 41. 2 years ago I couldn't even get more than 2 embies past day 3. I am a physician.  Started trying at 33y.  No success.  Countless IUI's.  One failed IVF cycle and one cancelled.  At 35y I was told to think about egg donors and they were willing to continue IVF but since I was a poor responder they did not think it would work.For the second IVF cycle I had already started having acupuncture and taking their herbs.  After leaning of the poor quality of the eggs retrieved...I sat in bed and researched poor responders.  I came across the information on DHEA.  My RE knows Casson and spoke with him about his study.  He is a believer in DHEA.  I started 25mg 3x day and in six weeks was pregnant.  We had a miscarriage at 10 weeks.  Went back on DHEA.  Three months after starting it up again my antral follicle count was much improved.  Few weeks later found out was pregnant again.  My RE wants to do a study on it since he saw the positive effects first hand.  He was very willing to try what I wanted to do and encourage you all to find an RE that wants to work with you.I am 31 weeks pregnant with a baby girl and am soo excited.I used the same DHEA from the Casson study, from Belmar Pharmacy...you can order by phone and they mail it out the next day or two.  I had acne and hair loss.  Controlled it with alternating 25mg 2xd and 3xd.  My side effects we well controlled.I had testosterone levels checked and they were high but not problematic and since my RE was working with me on this experiment he was watching and checking regularly.I continued acupuncture.Hope this helps.  Wish you luck.  It is such a hard road to do what we have all done to get pregnant!P

Well you are an interesting one. I went through my data and did several hours of research before responding. So here goes....Its too curious that your T is in a good range but your FSH is so high, especially for your age.Here's some relative comparisons to your numbers to show your uniquenessMy baseline DHEA was 392 and DHEA-S 66 with T=29 and free T=1.2pg/mL, FSH=10Your (repeating here) is 473 and DHEA-S 78 with T=76 and free T=1.0pg/mL, FSH=15PCOS is more like     10000 and DHEA-S 700 with T=120 and free T = 7 pg/mL, FSH = 3(the PCOS isn't from any specific data - but you get the idea)Normally, when T is high, FSH is low and vice versa. Because you're not quite fitting this typical spectrum I think you were smart to question and will be wise to look a bit further before adding DHEA.Here's what I would do if I were you......1. Have blood tests on Day 3 for the following hormones (day 21 is also an option if timing is poor and waiting is too hard (I can hardly ever wait myself ;)):ACTH, Cortisol, Dhea, Dhea-s, Androstenedione, T, free T, E2, Estrone, SHBG, IGF-1, EGF as well as Thyroid panel: TSH, T3 and T4All of these hormones are related and a disproprortionate level somewhere in the chain provides excellent pointer to the problem.Testosterone is supported by the Adrenal gland primarily and can also be effected by the thyroid gland.IF your doc says .. 'it's all in the normal range' and you get those good old #s in hard copy to see for yourself (just to be sure and also you can share here ;))....then, ok, I'd start the DHEA but at a low dose like 50mg in the am and test your T after a week. If its already over 100 then lower the dose or reconsider. If not I would probably cautiously move forward and bi-weekly test DHEA-S, T, IGF-1 and FSH twice a month afterward. This is really important I think in your case.Good news is that you're relatively young so if you can quickly focus on figuring this out then there is quite likely a solution and you can then be on your way to the baby farm. ;)I hope you'll post back here and share your findings. I'm really interested to see what the other levels look like and what your doc may have to say. Note - if your doc looks at you dumbfounded which they shouldn't but somehow often seem to.....you're just playing it safe and making sure no stone is left unturned.  You don't want to give up on your babies prematurely.A curious situation unsolved nags at me more than the average person...so I really hope you'll come back.You'll be in my thoughts...Sincerely,Anitasto

Q: Can DHEAQ be harmful or detrimental to a cycle?A: Yes – Great question and glad you asked. And this is most important. In lab rats high doses of DHEA have converted all normal females to PCOS females. In my last 2 months of DHEA I took A LOT of DHEA and, sure enough, my LH went high and ruined the last cycle which only resulted in 2 eggs, neither of which survived the thaw. I don’t want to write a book here but just to say….keep track of your Testosterone and LH, start at the 75 mg in the morning and increase gradually not more than 25mg more/2 weeks until you see what it does. 25mg can make a big difference. If you can get your T between 80 to 120 for a month before your cycle then you’ll rock.Q: I'm assuming I would have to tell my RE that I had been taking DHEA so they could supress early ovulation?A: Short answer – Yes. Make sure he’s doing LH tests along with the E2 from the beginning. And just so you can evaluate for yourself…an LH greater than 1.0 is enough to cancel a cycle. The ideal upper limit before HCG is 0.7 There are studies on or related to this by Fleming, 2000; Coppola, 2003, Ferrari, 2004.I think my reward is due too and hope like heck it works. But even if it doesn’t, this opportunity to help others is truly a reward in itself.Best of IVFing to you!-Anitasto

Blood clotting is a common cause of recurrent miscarriage and there are several different reasons for having blood that really likes to clot. Do you get clots commonly in your period???http://www.pregnancy-info.net/QA/answers-Using_Heparin_during_pregnancy_/7. I would definitely get tested for autoimmune antibodies. Q: My DHEAS is already high at 134.R: You may be confusing Testosterone and DHEAS values. 134 is a mid to low range for DHEAS but if it were Testosterone that would be high. So I think you can handle some DHEA.Q:Can you guys explain again the relationship between the Estrogen leves and DHEA levels?R: Based on my understanding and my own experience measuring available serum interim hormones in the chain....As your DHEA increases and flows through the hormone chain (which I'll spare you) at the end it increases FSH receptors in the follicles (based on study last year in Chile) and by a negative feedback less FSH is required for ovulation. With FSH reduced your baseline E2 is reduced also...though other hormones effect E2 this is the most relevant I think for DHEA. That's one reason I think a low dose of DHEA is good to start with when your baseline E2 is already pretty good. But your DHEAS will go up to a healthy level I think before it effects baseline E2I know...long answer. I gotta work on that. :)Hope this helps.Cheers,Anita

Never heard of low dose hcg during the cycle....but I got curious and did some reading..HCG and LH are biochemically almost identical and they're using HCG in place of LH because it lasts longer in the system and, when you're not pregnant, acts and effects exactly like LH.  There are studies that show small amounts of LH given during the cycle improve the outcomes.I didn't have this in my cycle but, reading more on it, I would ask for it if I were to cycle again. Sounds like your doc is up on his stuff. ;)fun fact - you can use an ovulation predictor test to also test pregnancy because it picks up the HCG as if it were LH. Tradeoff is OPK are lots cheaper just slightly less sensitive.Here's really good reading on HCG for LH in IVFhttp://doctor.medscape.com/viewarticle/532831Hope your garden is growing! ;)Cheers,Anitasto

Hi - I hope no one is offended by my jumping on this post, but I have skimmed and read most of the posts with interest.  Here's my story - did Clomid, injectables and one IVF - all failed!  I have an FSH of 3.something and my TSH is, now, 1.75 (will get another check tomorrow). Due to financial concerns, my DH and I decided to pursue a path of natural conception and have been with my new OB since Feb./March cycle!  (NaPro technology, if anyone's interested!)Anyway, this past cycle, he did a complete hormonal profile - I went in for b/w every other day for Estradiol checks and then once ovulation was confirmed, Estradiol and Progesterone.  7DPO, he did a range of tests, one of which was DHEA.I had read various things about the correlation of DHEA and fertility and was doubly curious due to my diagnosis of sub-clinical hypothyroidism. (Knew that they were connected somehow...) However, I was very uncomfortable with self-medicating on this particular hormone and wanted to trust the advice of people caring for me (my OB, chiropractor and my acupuncturist)So, my DHEA came in at 95, to which the doc said 'it's on the low side.'  He wants to see it in the 200's.  He prescribed DHEA (which I get from a Compounding Pharmacy, so they make it there and it's PURE DHEA) at 25 mg once a day.  I will also get this re-tested tmw, so I'll let you know if there has been any change.I was chatting with my acupuncturist about how I have instantly responded to the DHEA (more energy, less depression, lessened fibromyalgia symptoms) and I was telling her about this post and my re-check tmw.  She said to be sure that testosterone was being re-checked because it needs to stay low in order to not affect your uterine lining and thin it out, preventing implantation.  I told her that I had read that some women were taking upwards of 75 mg per day of DHEA and she was IMMEDIATELY concerned.She said that was a very high dosage (per her, 25 is standard for women and 50 is standard for men)....she said that at that dosage, testosterone checks should be happening because DHEA can raise it and counter the very thing that we are trying to accomplish.I just thought that I would share the information as I received it!  Sorry for the long post!Thanks!

Here is what I found on the Internet regarding DHEA and Hypothryoidism:Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is a steroid produced by the adrenal glands and is the most abundant one found in humans. DHEA may be transformed into testosterone, estrogen or other steroids. It is found in the body as DHEA or in the sulfated form known as DHEA-S. One form is converted into the other as needed.Cortisol and DHEA are among the hormones produced by the adrenal glands. It is possible that these hormones can reduce the immune system dysfunction seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis. More studies are needed, but taking these medications appropriately carries little (if any) risk and can markedly improve the patient's function and overall health.

RE: Pregnancy on DHEADear all,I wanted to chime in with my story, which I hope will be encouraging for all.  Am in my early 30s with diminished ovarian reserve (FSH as high as 13, low Inhibin B, low-ish antral follicle counts).  Did a Clomid + IUI cycle with no luck, then an IVF, also with no luck.  I only produced 5 eggs during the IVF cycle, even though we did the short protocol, and the fertilization rate and embryo quality weren't good (two out of five fertilized, and only one of those made it to be a 4-cell day 3 embryo).  After the failed IVF, I started taking 75 mg/day of DHEA to gear up for another IVF, and got pregnant on my second DHEA cycle.  I was also taking Clomid at the time and we just found out that it's twins!  Who knows what happened, but it seems that the DHEA gave me a boost of something that I needed in order to produce better-quality eggs.  We'll see if the pregnancies work out; even if not, it seems to be a great sign that two out of two eggs fertilized and have been developing for a few weeks.  I also did acupuncture and took wheatgrass pills and flax seed oil.  My doctor told me to stop taking the DHEA as soon as we got the positive pregnancy test.Wishing you all the best of luck,Ann

Hi Lynnny...I just wanted to chime in here on your RE's comment - because I received a similar comment from an RE I saw previously, unfortunately I never questioned what he said and we spent lots of $ pursuing a course of treatment that may not have been right for me based on his 'misdiagnosis'.  Sorry in advance for my soapbox rant, but I feel very passionate about drs "diagnosing" without actually running any tests!During a phone consult this 'well respected' RE he stated that his practice believes all older women have high levels of testosterone (the male hormone) and he follows a specific protocol to counteract that high T.  He does not believe in DHEA because of the risk to increasing that T (though I found that out long after I'd left him; I didn't know about DHEA back then).  What I never questioned until much later (after failed IVFs) was how he determined I had high T - he made this 'diagnosis' during a phone consult - he had all of my medical records but I had never had my T tested before, so did he make this 'diagnosis' by listening to me?Once I started reading about DHEA I decided to get tested through my OB-GYN.  I had a baseline DHEA and DHEA-S but did not have Testosterone tested until I'd been on DHEA supplements for almost 2 weeks.  That T test showed I had very low T - by that time it may have even been raised by the DHEA I had been supplementing. So that RE's guess about my "high T" was completely off-base.Unless your RE actually tested your "male hormone" levels he has no basis to state what your male hormone level may be.  If he won't test your levels go to your OB-GYN or your family dr. (Anitasto has provided great info on basic 3 tests to get).If you feel you need an explanation for requesting the tests - you can always tell them your acupucturist wants to put you on DHEA for fertility but from what you've read you'd feel more comfortable understanding what your levels are before actually starting any supplements.Good luck!Lynne

This is a long post – but I’ve spent much time considering and trying these and this has really all the best advice I can offer to get your bloodwork (preferably with the same person who’s doing your cycles). So please bear with and read thru.HERE ARE SOME QUICK AND EASY CHECKS YOU CAN DO TO FIND SUPPORT FOR DHEA BLOODWORK................Call accupuncturists in your area that specialize in fertility. My local fertility acupuncturist knows every RE in this town backward and forward because she works with them. I imagine its similar in most towns.Post on this blog the town you live in and ask for referrals from gals here. You could get very lucky. I’m in San Diego and can offer great resources here.Contact your PCP and let them know you're situation and ask if they can check adrenal function with DHEA-S, T (free and total) with day 3 fertility panel FSH, E2, LH. Most PCPs are pretty agreeable with this and tests are inexpensive. But they will order they're own stuff - so be sure to tell them what you want specifically.ON TRYING TO FIND AN RE WHO WILL DO DHEA REALATED BLOODWORK.......Imagine this analogy - humor me here...You’re in a delicate dance with a big hungry bear (yes...he wants your ivf $$). If you remain calm and make just the right steps, you can get the bear to dance with you. If you appear aggressive or turse….well….the bear will eat you and move on. If you are too meak and play dead...well... the bear will not be interested in you, walk over you and then walk away. I hate to say it....but this is life. And this is how I’ve felt in searching for an RE and even working with him until we struck the right balance of mutual respect. And that took six months of displaying consistent calm but determination.In trying to get RE cooperation (not support – you’re unlikely to find it) it’s really important to back up your requests with good research. They will take you much more seriously.If you want to try with your current RE I would fax or deliver a copy of Casson on DHEA and IVF in 2000 (free on inet), Gleicher on DHEA in 2005 and 2006 (the case study of one woman with 66 embryos and the followup study with 26 or so women on DHEA.) If you need copies post your email and I’ll send them all to you. Otherwise Casson is free online and Gleicher's are about $5 I think as a patient. Ask your doctor to review those and ask if you can talk with him in about a week. This gives you time to check around so you have backup if you need it.In the meantime….CONTACT REs AND ANY OTHER ENDOCRYNOLOGIST YOU CAN FIND CLOSE TO HOME - ESPECIALLY WITH FOCUS ON FERTILITY (many do thyroid and diabetes only). Antiaging is also pretty good...these folks seem to be most well rounded in their understanding of the endocrine system.ASK FOR A PHONE CONSULT. Almost all of them give free phone consults or some have a set fee for a consult….they do them all the time.OTHER RESOURCES................Also contact any PCP who is a woman especially in her 40s. Most of these will likely be kindred spirits in your plight and willing to help. But like Garden, having to see 2 different doctors is not ideal unless you just have a lot of time. But even then, it will wear on you eventually.HOW TO ASK...WHAT TO SAY...IMPORTANT TONE AND APPROACHAnd a very important thing I think….. I would really avoid asking what any RE or other doctor what they think about DHEA if I were you. You will get as many different answers as there are REs and once they’ve stated a negative opinion it is very hard for them to save face and agree to help you. Asking their opinion just opens the door to conflict when your opinions differ.After telling them about your failed cycles and sincere desire to have your own children…I would only say “…..I am planning to use DHEA and would so much appreciate if you will be able to add bloodwork for DHEA-S and T prior to and during the cycle. Is this something you can do?”I write this script because the wording is really important here. You’re not asking what they think or what they are willing to do. You’re asking if they ‘can’…which the answer of course is yes…they can do anything they want.  If they say no then they simply don’t want to do it and that’s ok too and best to find out early. You WILL find support with this sweet, kind, educated and sincere request. If you strike out more than twice…I would even be willing to make calls on your behalf. I mean this seriously.ON AN RE WHO HAS ALREADY SPOKEN NEGATIVELY ABOUT DHEA.........When you talk again with your RE and he says he has read the articles (which you sent and asked him to review) but is not comfortable or anything negative which you should expect…. then I would say….“....I really appreciate your taking the time to talk with me further and I do understand  this is different from what we discussed. I would really like to try this next if you could allow me to do that. Would you be willing to consider Gleicher’s protocol?”If he agrees to this…..you’re home. And in this case you have to say ‘willing’ because he’s already stated a position so you are in fact asking him to bend and recognizing it. This will give you ‘humble’ points and make it difficult to refuse you.CONSIDER PRACTICING YOUR APPROACH AHEAD OF TIME.......If you have a difficult time taking a position like this…e.g. you’re generally shy or avoid conflict at all cost or are intimidated by doctors (most of us are)…then practice these scripts with DH or a girlfriend. Same goes if you tend to run the other way...bull in a china shop...  ;) And if you have a confident and diplomatic friend, consider asking them to call on your behalf. This is probably not necessary but I've been asked by a few girlfriends at different times to go with them to REs and other important stuff to advocate and its always been an honor to help them get what they need.I think it is so very important to find the support you need in order to ensure you are getting successful outcome with DHEA. Most can do well without it but you don't want to be the one who really needs it and waste time. DH and I spent 6 months without DHEA, 4 more months without good support, and then had DHEA complications that took a year to figure out that we never would have without bloodwork support. As many of you know, we did get 10 eggs in a cycle on DHEA .... 2 1/2 years earlier in our first IVF we only ever saw 1 follicle.I sincerely hope you ladies find this helpful.All the best,Anitasto

I just wanted to thank Anitasto and the others of you that have shared your journeys so openly - I have been watching this with interest over the last few weeks and have found it all so fascinating and helpful.I hope you don't mind - but here is a little bit on me:  My DH and I started IVF in April for PGD purposes only - we had no idea that there were any issues with me (I am only 32) and DH's trial wash was perfect.  After 3 days of stimming on cycle 1 my FSH was increased from 150u to 300u and the cycle later cancelled for poor response. Cycle 2 was also cancelled.  Cycle 3 we had determined that I had poor ovarian response, though my FSH readings at the beginning of a cycle are all normal - in fact I was told that all my hormone levels are normal at the beginning, but my E is slow to rise during a cycle and I just seem to have a low follicle count on every cycle.  Cycle 3 we had 8 follicles, and retrieved 6 eggs. Only 3 could be ICSI'd - 2 of those fertilised abnormally and the final one was graded poor and didnt get past 5 cells.  I was scared that the quality was all so poor and we were told to prepare ourselves for never having our own children, though not to give up all hope yet.My Dr then put me on DHEA - I havent had my levels tested however I can say that we then started another cycle after only 1 month on the DHEA - sadly we only got 4 eggs - I was devastated - but all 4 fertilised normally and all 4 got to blastocyst stage (though 2 were too slow to get to PGD testing in time).  2 were good enough to be PGD tested on day 6, 1 passed the PGD and was transferred - unfortunately no BFP but what a difference from cycle 3 to cycle 4.  I am now back on the DHEA and will also do an oestrogen priming protocol this cycle.  I am also about to start acupuncture.  I am not sure if any of you have any suggestions - my Dr says that adding the oestrogen priming is the last trick in her book - however I am hopeful that if we just keep on going that we will get there eventually.  I am not exactly sure how the Oestrogen priming helps?I am also interested in whether DHEA can increase or decrease miscarriage rates and notice that the CHR state that their research shows as follows:'This is why the timing of the arrival of the Toronto data was so exciting; these data not only confirmed the high pregnancy rate in very unfavorable patients with diminished ovarian reserve, but demonstrated an identical reduction in miscarriage rate to the one observed by us (when compared to national IVF data). Since the combined data sets between CHR and the Toronto center involve an adequate size patient sample, we are now confident to state that DHEA supplementation significantly decreases the miscarriage rate in women with diminished ovarian reserve.'http://www.centerforhumanreprod.com/premature_ovaries.htmlDoes anyone know anything about DHEA and miscarriage rates - ie if I manage to get to transfer again do I stop taking the DHEA or not, and if I stop - when should I stop????

Welcome Hope!  Finding this string has been a great source of info for me too and the more people that contribute, the more we'll all learn!Thank you for sharing your story - my heart goes out to you for your cycle failures but it sounds like you have reason to be optimistic from your last cycle with DHEA!Regarding your question on miscarriages... I'd have to go back through the post to be sure, but I believe it was Anitasto that wrote that CHR had a higher miscarriage rate because they left people on DHEA through transfer up to the first or second positive beta.  I'm not sure what the right answer is - I've read Dr. Gleicher at CHR state that "There is no evidence to suggest that DHEA is harmful. PCOD patients, who get pregnant all the time, have very high DHEA levels.  Pregnancy, itself, is a high DHEA state since the placenta is a DHEA factory." (so presumable supplementing into the early pregnancy shouldn't be a problem).  But I'm inclined to take the conservative approach and follow Anitasto's advise that DHEA supplementing be ended with transfer since it tends to increase a woman's testosterone and high T can lead to m/c (or at least pull back on the amount taken... then again if you're getting blood tests throughout your cycle like Anitasto suggests, you'll know what your T levels are and make an assessment whether there is a risk of high T / continuing DHEA).(Note - the comments from Dr. Gleicher were from a phone consult a woman on IVFconnections.com had with him in 2005 and posted to that board; she reconfirmed that info with him again in May this year.)

Hi everyone!I have read your posts with great interest because I have started to take DHEA despite my fertility specialist's request that I stop taking all meds and vitamins unless he prescribed it.I'll briefly share my story:  I was treated for a hyperthyroid when I was 27 years old, my periods became scant and eventually stopped, which I now believe was caused by the medication I took.  I was diagnosed with premature ovarian failure at the age of 30, FSH of 120, with menopausal symptoms and no follicles.  My husband and I were devastated.We were told we had exactly one option:  IVF with donor eggs.  We've had 3 IVFs (2 fresh, one frozen, with 2 different donors).  NO BFP.  The doctors talk about using donor eggs as though it's as close to a sure thing as we can get with IVF.  We've spent for than $60 000.00 (due largely to the $23 000.00 we spent on the first donor, through an agency).Now there's news DHEA may help women with premature ovarian failure, too.  In a recent Greek study, available at www.neogenesis.gr, 5 women with POF became pregnant while using an off-the-shelf DHEA product from Natural Organics Laboratories Inc.  I purchased some yesterday, switching brands so I could take DHEA that is similar to the type used in this particular study.  The closest I could find is "Nature's Plus" DHEA (25 mg) capsules, from the same manufacturer.  I'm stopping my hormone replacement therapy this month and I'm going to see how I respond to just DHEA.  I do seem to have some hair loss, but I'm not going to fret about it unless it becomes noticeable.Thank you for sharing your stories with me.  It's so nice to know that I'm not alone!Laura

Hope02,Hi Hope. And welcome also. I’m sooo excited to hear another doctor freely adding DHEA. Sounds like your in great hands.A couple things from your post along with other posts on estrogen sent me searching…..And here’s the thing, just like estrogen during stims I didn’t find a study but on estrogen priming I did find some blogs. Here’s a quote from one, “I talked to the nurse at Dr. Swanson and asked her if they do estrogen priming as part of the antagonist protocol.  She said no, they used to, but they weren't getting a good response.”  Her doc is proposing estrogen priming by taking it 4 weeks before stimming. Here’s the link: http://wombmatewanted.typepad.com/blog/estrogen-priming/index.htmlMy theory on estrogen priming is that with DHEA its critical to downregulate the ovaries for 2 weeks, starting immediately after ovulation, just before stimming. I don’t like the 4 weeks of estrogen because then you don’t ovulate so your ovaries don’t get LH which is important to the health of future follicles. I once did Estrogen for 3 weeks instead of 2 for scheduling purposes and follies started disappearing after 12 days of Estrogen so I wouldn’t do it again. Also, CHR – which started this whole thing after Casson – uses 2 weeks on Estrogen patches prior to stims, 3 days off everything but baby aspirin and vits, then stims – this worked for me very well.We’ve had different approaches on this blog to going off and staying on DHEA after transfer. If I were to go again, I would just cut my DHEA down to 50mg after retrieval and 25mg after PPT. Some quit after retrieval all together, some quit after 2 ppt. My email on this question to CHR got a response that they do not stop the DHEA supplements after transfer.As for miscarriage. I think its pretty straightforward. Most of us see better quality eggs and embryos on dhea. It thus should follow that there should be fewer miscarriages.Its easy to worry about everything – but the acupuncture will definitely help you relax. I think it sounds like you’re going to do really just fine in this next cycle given your fert rate this time.BTW – DH and I did pgd without PG results. We are doing 3 day xfer next time. Most dhea’ers are doing 3day xfers. Just a thought.Finally - I think your instincts are right – keep doing what you’re doing and just get your bloodwork to see that your T is close to 100 and you have increased number of antral follies before starting stims to be sure you $$ are being very well spent.Looking forward to hearing how it all goes!Sincerely,Anitasto

I keep having afterthoughts about you....it must be the wine! hehe.Your LH levels are slightly concerning. The gold standard as I understand it based on many studies is that LH should be between 0.5 and 1.7 at HCG injection before retrieval. Yours fortunately appears to be going down on CD 3 while you're on DHEA. But it should be lower on CD3....like below 0.5. And this now also leads me to question the use of HCG in your cycle. I could understand if your LH was 0.0 and never went up, but if he's adding HCG and then also adding Ganirelix to avoid ovulation its kind of chicken and the egg. Make sense?I'd just get your labs like you do and follow that LH and don't add that HCG if your LH is over 0.5 and once you see 0.7 definitely start the ganirelix.Here's a link that lists the studies and their standards.http://humupd.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/12/1/3/T8?ck=nckHere's the best study I think....http://humupd.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/12/1/3?ck=nck#T8Let me know your thoughts. My last cycle had LH of 5+ and our eggs were ****. That's the problem with high LH. I seriously regretted allowing my doc to do the retrieval knowing the LH and responsibly he should have canceled it. Ugh!Sweet dreams my fellow blogmeister. ;)Anitasto

Thank you for your information and concerns! ;)The problem with HRT is, I was basically left to sort that out by myself, with the help of my naturopath.  My family doctor didn't know how much estrogen and progesterone I should take, or the type, and after the first two BFNs the fertility clinic never called me again.  It's heinous, really.  I asked the fertility specialist what I should take, he said I should be in the care of my family doctor, and the family doctor didn't want to interfere with the fertility clinic's advice.Bottom line:  they don't know how to deal with women whose ovaries don't work properly, as POF occurs in only 1% of women 35 and younger.Here's the HRT protocol I figured out on my own:  Day 1 - 20, 1 tablet of estrace (2mg) in the morning.  On day 21, I stop the estrace and use 1 progesterone suppository at bedtime, nightly until I get my period, around day 28.  If I do the progesterone around day 15, which was information I found online, then my period arrives around day 20.I thought I'd go off HRT for one month and just use DHEA and see if my cycle returns with DHEA,  as was mentioned in the Greek study.  It's a good sign that I menstruate on the hormones;  my naturopath said truly menopausal women don't have any menstrual blood flows, even when taking HRT.A few weeks ago, we had our third IVF.  This time, I had LOTS of bleeding when I wasn't supposed to, and thought the transfer may be cancelled.  There was lots of clotting mid way through the cycle, when I was increasing the estrogen.  On day 14 of my cycle I had a full, five day, very heavy period, followed by lots of spotting.  It's a dramatic change from a year ago, when I had a tough time bleeding, even after taking provera.  Then we started some massive doses of estrogen to get me ready for the transfer, and I spotted all the way up until the day before.Anyway, you're right about bloodwork, and I'll call the family doctor and see what he thinks...Thanks, Ladies!Laura

Some info on AMH (supposedly this is to replace the FSH and the antral follicle count as more accurate):http://www.canigetpregnant.co.uk/Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a new blood test developed following clinical research which measures ovarian function – how your ovaries are working. It is more accurate than a simple oestrogen test. Currently it is not available on the NHS.It can help reassure women about their current and medium term fertility – important when deciding when to try for children ,especially for women who work. It can also help to predict a likely menopause, and is starting to be used by some clinics to help judge possible IVF success and also as a marker of polycystic ovarian syndrome – a common hormonal condition.http://www.canigetpregnant.co.uk/results.php28.6 - 48.5 pmol/l  You have the green light: You are safe to wait for at least another two years before having children15.7 - 28.6 pmol/l You have the green light: Test result indicating good AMH levels2.2 - 15.7 pmol/l  You have the amber light: You should start to think about having children within the next two yearsLess than 2 pmol/l  You have the red light: If you have been trying for children, please see your doctor

Hi Betsy. Sorry it took me so long to follow up on the inhibin B question. Turns out I had tested Interleukins as they are associated with attachment of the embryo. So no comparison Inhibin B test for you - sorry.But I did do some digging. You may already know this but...just in case and for others...Inhibin B is secreted by the granulosa cells which are the early cells of a follicle and multiply as it grows. It is very much like measuring FSH...e.g. high FSH then few follies, low Inhibin B then few follies.The good news is that becacuse Inhibin B is secreted by granulosa cells, there's no reason to conclude that a low measurement will result in FEW follies after DHEA ultimately results in MORE GRANULOSA CELLS because it results in more follies.If possible, it would b great if you could get your RE to retest your Inhibin B on Day 3 before your next cycle with your other labs. It should be increased. If your experiment is successful then maybe we dheaers could use inhibin B on day 3 as another marker that the dhea is working.http://www.medvet.umontreal.ca/crra_ang/CAP_inhibine.pdfHope this is helpful my dear.Anitasto

Dg223,First of all – great job on keeping up with your blood levels. I know you’re nervous, I was totally nervous too. But before going into detail, just want to start by saying that I think you’re ok and don’t need to change anything right now.That said….here are my thoughts…An excerpt from Casson’s study “DHEA supplementation enhances serum free IGF-I concentrations by ~150%, probably independently of changes in GH secretion”I looked this up because your IGF-1 is going up and SHBG going down even though slightly there should be a more marked change to the opposite. I looked at my own labs historical spreadsheet of bloodwork and then remembered – IGF-1 oscillates with your cycle.  My IGF-1 was close to baseline on CD3 but increased about 150% on CD21. Forexample, my first IGF-1 on 11/14 CD3 was 152. On 12/01 CD21 it was 215. Ithen had a cyst and cycle messed up but next compare…cd21 on 12/19 it was 200 and then on cd3 01/02 it was 160. Soooo…I’m not surprised based on that if your IGF-1 didn’t increase. However, it would be nice to see your SHBG go down. This is not so critical, however, as long as your Free Testosterone is going up. SHBG binds up hormones and keeps them from acting on other cells…not so great…but you probably have higher free T so shouldn’t be a big deal.SO – if possible – ask your sis to call the lab and add on T free (just fyi always request T free and total) and E2.The reason for E2 in particular is…it may explain why your FSH zoomed so high. It’s kind of like clomid. Clomid works by blocking estrogen receptors in the brain so it shovels out FSH which gives you more follies. With high T, as I’ve said here before, I believe your true baseline E2 goes down. In my case it once went like in the teens and at the same time my FSH shot up to 15. We handled it by putting on Vivelle dot patches/estrogen patches at 15 days into my cycle. This prepped the ovaries by quieting them down before the cycle, and also stabilized my fsh to its tue baseline of about 4.1 when my T was around 100.Just one more thing, if your sis can get the lab to do it, ask for GH and free IGF-1. I’m partially curious but also if the others don’t come back as expected it will be more info.The palpatations are ok, I had them for quite a while at that range when I first started before my body adjusted. Be sure you are taking baby aspirin at least twice a day and drinking PLENTY of fluids to offset the added blood thickening that occurs with dhea and greater red blood cell count.Most important. Relax. Don’t drink alcohol or extra sugary stuff and after you ovulate ask for the Vivelle dot patch….I wore 2/day as it took that much to keep my hyperactive ovaries quiet. I tried oral estrogen but it didn’t do it.Last but not least – have your DHEA-s and T drawn again in about a week. If your T goes over 150 then I would step it back. I suspect thought that you should be leveling off at or below 120.Hang in there babe! You’re doing great! :)Anitasto

Hi AnitastoYou are a godsend for helping us all out with your knowledge - honestly you should start charging for your services!!As for more info on me - my life story and stats in a paragraph (or two)Went on the pill at age 15 as was getting a period every 2 weeks.  Went off the pill at age 20.  Within 6 months back to bleeding every two weeks (and not just some light spotting) so went back on the pill - took 7 pill changes before I found one that could stop the period every 2 weeks - Diane 35.  Dr's said that the period every 2 weeks was a great thing - it meant that I was super fertile!!!!  Stayed on the pill until I met my husband - he has a rare skin condition -epidermolysis bullosa - has the dominant condition and is a carrier of the recessive - I havent been tested for the recessive but chances are slim that I would have it - tis a death sentence for our child if I do.  We explored IVF PGD for genetic purposes only as my husband felt strongly about not passing his skin on.  No known fertility issues.  In fact I still thought i was 'super fertile'!!  First IVF cycle in April 08 (I am 32 and my husband 28) - long down reg cycle - FSH doubled after 3 days to 300u as I was not responding - cycled cancelled after 8 days stimming.  Period arrived 6 days later (this didnt surprise me with my history though my FS was surprised) Cycle 2 antagonist started on first day of period - after BT which showed my hormones had baselined.  Cycle 2 cancelled after 4 days due to oestrogen producing cyst.  Trigger injection given and period arrived 10 days later.  Cycle 3 started - antagonist - 300u daily from the start - got to EPU - 8 follies, 6 eggs, - of these: 1 was 'cracked', 2 were immature, 2/3 that fertilised were abnormal despite the ICSI (1 had 3 pronuclei and the other 1).  The final egg got to 5 cells was fragmenting badly and didnt go furhter.  Dr said that things werent looking and that we needed to prepare ourselves for not having our own children - said that to get 3 pronuclei doing ICSI was highly unusual.  She also said though that she wasnt out of ideas and suggested I try DHEA.  I guess the fact that we know that 50% of our embryos will have my husbands condition means that we really need more eggs - or will need to do lots of cycles - we are prepared for this, now.  We then almost immediately started cycle 4 - my FS said that we could take a break but she thought that the FSH in my system from the last few cycles could also help with quality - I also immediately started taking DHEA 75mg (even though Dr only prescribed 50mg a day - I had found this post within days of starting the dhea)  I have been having 50mg in the morning and 25mg at night - not sure if I should change this to all inthe morning??  Cycle 4 - long down reg - started on 400u daily FSH.  Again had 8 follies - 4 eggs at EPU - all 4 fertilised normally, 2 made it to the necessary blastocyst stage by day 6 for biopsy and were good enough quality for biopsy (though were rated fair not good) - 1 was unaffected and transferred - BFN.  I stopped taking the DHEA on the day of EPU under my Dr's advice but recommenced as soon as I got the BFN - was only off it for about 2 weeks in total.  EPU for this cycle was on July 4 - I am now getting ready for cycle 5 - and was going to start the lucrin on Monday - however my BT results came back at E - 100, LH - 11, and P - 0 :  which my Dr says is baseline.  Hence as of yesterday I am now back on the pill and still taking the DHEA.  I dont know what it means at all that I have been on DHEA for a couple of months now with only a short break and my hormones are so low on day 19 of a natural cycle???Anyways - wow what  a post - I think that is pretty much all the info that i can give you (other than that my husbands swimmers have been tested and are all really good - so any issues it would seem are with me) - any thoughts you have or possible solutions would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks again for your help.  HOpe

All of the information posted is very helpful. Even though a lot of the abbreviations don't mean a lot to me. Let me tell you my story...I am 42 years old and am considered obese. I finally married for the first time at the ripe old age of 39. My husband had been married previously, but had never had any children. Before marriage I had resigned that I would be a single, childless spinster. After marriage, we could think of nothing else.We went to the doctor, and were given the odds (due to my weight). My husband was tested and given thumbs up on count and motility (and something else, but I have forgotten now). However it was discovered that I do not ovulate every month.My doctor prescribed Clomid. which we took for over a year and nothing happened. Then in August of last year, my doctor was on vacation and the on-call-doctor refused to refill my prescription (said she found no evidence of it, which really made my doctor mad when she returned). When it came time for my cycle to start in Sept, I didn't. I was pregnant. Unfortunately, it didn't last for very long. I miscarried 2 days before our 2nd anniversary (great gift, huh?)We were devastated and heart-broken. But my doctor assured me that we did this on our own, and that means we could do it again.Well, it's been almost a year since the miscarriage, and nothing. I was afraid to go back on the Clomid because I had heard that it could cause cancer. But my doctor tells me that there is no evidence supporting that. I start taking Clomid again this Sunday, and have started taking DHEA today (after reading everything I can possibly find on the subject)I have not told my doctor about the DHEA, but I have an appointment to see her on the 18th and will discuss it with her then. I am a little afraid of what she might say, but I really can't waste anymore time. At the rate things are going, I will 50 before I get pregnant! But I have faith in God and medicine! In the meantime I will continue to read this thread. It is very inspiring.Keep your fingers crossed that we can do this!prg5266

Hope02,Thanks for posting your story. It sounds like you’ve really been through the ringer. It does sound though like the DHEA made a difference in your last cycle. And its so great that your RE recommened it for you. Whatever the issue with your current levels whether annovulation or lack of progesterone production, it appears your IVF is overcoming these so I hope you can take comfort in that. Below are comments and questions for you to see if we can draw some conclusions together.“I dont know what it means at all that I have been on DHEA for a couple of months now with only a short break and my hormones are so low on day 19 of a natural cycle??? “Your E2 seems fine for a single follicle. Your P=0 just means you didn’t ovulate….as I’m sure you understand. This can happen on DHEA too, especially if you had a tendency to be annovulatory prior to DHEA. I believe this happened to me in 2 cycles on DHEA. Your LH level just means you haven’t yet or aren’t going to ovulate. Again, not so surprising if you didn’t ovulate before DHEA. Why are your cycles 2 weeks? Typically it’s a luteal phase defect and either your ovulating but producing no progesterone or not ovulating at all.If you weren’t ovulating before or have a luteal phase defect then DHEA will not ‘necessarily’ always repair this, but IVF can overcome it. It would be good to confirm this either way though.Here are some questions for you..1. What were your baselines in the past on day 3ish for FSH and E2?2. Have you ever done a home LH test to verify ovulation? If you don’t ovulate, then of course you wouldn’t have Progesterone. But its possible to ovulate and have little to none. LH is also valuable for egg quality and…given your quality….I’m curious. These are cheap at Walmart …… if you haven’t tried this before…if you start testing now we could see if you get to ovulation before your flow.3. Was your progesterone ever tested at any time during your short cycles prior to ivf? A lot of women are short on progesterone and have shorter cycles and its easily solved with supplements. I’m sure you probably know this stuff but just wanted to cover the bases.4. Have you had any BW on DHEA, DHEA-s and Testosterone (T)? This will also be helpful. I’m guessing these are low for your age because of quality and you’re still getting 8 eggs as a reflection of your age….so its not terribly low like us old timers here. ;)5. Do you workout a lot…how much?6. Do you drink….how much?7. Are you particularly lean?I don’t know but, like dg223, you’ve peaked my interest and I’ll stay with you in trying to solve the puzzle if you feel determined.I’d love to get paid for this….if you or anyone you know has a link to a publisher please feel free to put us in touch. I’ve drafted 6 chapters so far. ;)Look forward to your info.Best,Anitasto

Couple of info bytes on follicle growth to help understand why DHEA and T help us out….Follicles are predominantly composed of Testosterone until they are about 7-8mm after which they convert to Estrogen dominance. (This is why I think baseline follie scan should show all follies at or below 7mm instead of 10mm…10 is not optimal and those follies have already begun synthesizing FSH and will horde it from the others generally speaking. This is especially true if you tend to have lead follicle(s)). The follicular fluid, in addition to T, also has DHEA and other goodies. The only T that can go into these guys is Free Testosterone since the rest is bound to Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG). If you exercise A LOT, your T can be lowered by synthesis to proteins to build or repair muscles (anyone please correct me on this if I’ve stated it wrong or not fully enough). I tested it also after workout and then when I wasn’t working out. My Sunday 20 mile bike race dropped it in half two times in a row. So I quit that….though probably should have still done like 5 miles for circulation….and it climbed and maintained at over 80 pg/ml. I tested the effect of alcohol also and it dropped my T by 2/3 after like 5 shots of rum. There’s not a lot of literature on this but there was some.
